title: A Multiscale Study of MOFs as Adsorbents in H
PSA Purification
abstract: In this multiscale study, four robust zirconium oxide based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) were examined using powerful molecular simulation tools as well as indispensable full-scale PSA system modeling to determine their potential for H

purification. Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were employed to evaluate the MOF working capacities, binary-mixture selectivities, and micropore transport diffusivities for each of the components of a steam methane reformer offgas (SMROG) stream: H
. The small, functionalized pores of UiO-66(Zr)-Br were found to result in high N
and CO selectivities and working capacities, whereas the slightly larger pore volume of UiO-66(Zr) favored higher CO
working capacities. The collective impact of impurity uptakes and selectivities on the purification of H

from five-component steam methane reformer offgas mixtures was investigated through PSA column modeling. The breakthrough behavior of SMROG mixtures in columns containing MOF crystallites was determined using the simulated adsorption and diffusivity data as input. MOF breakthrough curves for single and two-layered beds were compared to those of commercial adsorbents including Zeolite 5A and Calgon PCB. Two of the MOFs, namely, UiO-66(Zr) and UiO-66(Zr)-Br, were found to have longer dimensionless breakthrough times than the commercial zeolite materials and are therefore expected to result in larger yields of high-purity H
per PSA cycle. UiO-66(Zr)-Br was found to be the most promising of the four MOFs, having the longest dimensionless breakthrough times in both single and two-layered bed setups.

PSA units require high-performance adsorbents that have large capacities and selectivities for the impurities to be removed and can be easily regenerated at low pressure.
Feed streams generally enter a PSA process at 4–30 atm, whereas the waste streams containing desorbed impurities leave the columns at 1.1–1.7 atm.

Depending on the process temperature and pressure, frequently utilized adsorbents include activated aluminas, silica gels, activated carbons (ACs), and zeolites. Activated carbons are beneficial for the removal of CO
and hydrocarbons because of their high capacities and low adsorption enthalpies; however, their nonpolar structures and large pore diameters render them less advantageous in the removal of N
and CO. Zeolites, on the other hand, have high selectivities for polar adsorbates but are difficult to regenerate upon CO
adsorption because of the high interaction strength between the CO

molecules and the charged zeolite pore surface. To increase separation efficiency, adsorption columns often contain two or more adsorbent layers, each of which is designed to target specific impurities.

The overall performance of the PSA unit is highly dependent on the adsorbents chosen and is limited by the selectivity of the adsorbent for the most weakly interacting impurity, which is N
in the case of SMROG. Once this impurity breaks through the adsorption column, the feed cycle must be stopped, and the adsorbent must be regenerated.

In the continuous search for high-performance adsorbent materials required to improve PSA product yield, purity, and energy requirements, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been identified as promising candidates. Whereas many MOF studies have focused on the adsorption of binary and ternary mixtures
containing the more abundant impurities (i.e., CO
), only a few have analyzed CO/H

mixture adsorption. It is important to bear in mind that PSA performance is determined by the adsorption behavior of each of the impurities and that adsorption strength can vary widely depending on the polarity of the impurity and the properties of the MOF such as pore size, topology, and chemical functionality. Furthermore, the impurities compete with each other for the available adsorption sites; therefore, to identify the most promising MOFs for H

purification, a study of both the adsorption and micropore and macropore diffusion behaviors of the complete mixture is required. A study of diffusion through the micropores is necessary to verify the dominant mass-transfer resistance.

According to the detailed report of Sircar and Golden, the criteria by which PSA adsorbents should be selected include multicomponent adsorption capacities, desorption behavior, selectivities, and isosteric heats of adsorption.
None of these factors, however, can be used as a single selection criterion, as separation efficiency is affected by each parameter to some degree.
The most effective method for testing the selective properties of materials to be used in separating H
from multicomponent mixtures is the use of laboratory-scale breakthrough and PSA cycle experiments, such as the dual-piston PSA setup,

as well as mathematical models that simulate column adsorption. As a result, numerous zeolite and activated carbon studies seeking to identify promising PSA adsorbents have presented breakthrough studies and PSA process modeling for multicomponent H
mixtures through both single and layered beds.

Recently, breakthrough models were employed to investigate whether MOFs can be used in PSA separations for various applications with mixtures containing up to four gases. A study carried out by Krishna and Long compared several MOFs to zeolites and activated carbons using breakthrough studies of CO
mixtures, as well as binary combinations of the three gases.

A typical SMROG stream to be introduced into a hydrogen purification PSA unit contains H

Water is also normally present; however, it is the most strongly adsorbed component and can be easily removed from the stream either prior to the PSA unit or by using additional adsorbent layers in the PSA column. In this study, the stream entering the PSA column was assumed to be water-free. Considering the wide variation in selectivities not only from one MOF to another but also from one impurity to another, it is critical to include all mixture components in the modeling of breakthrough curves. In this work, we used a combination of powerful simulation tools to perform a multiscale study on the progression of five-component mixtures, consisting of both weakly interacting gases such as N
and CO and easily adsorbed gases such as CH

, through columns containing four MOFs. Whereas PSA studies in the literature are normally carried out, at least partially, through experimental work, we present an entirely computational study enabled by a transition from simulations at the molecular level to simulations performed on the scale of unit operations. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time such a study, focusing on H
purification from SMROG, has been published.

Both the selectivity plots and the working capacities present valuable information about the potential of each MOF as a PSA adsorbent for H
purification. However, our results show that a MOF might be very promising in some aspects while showing limitations in others. Based on its high selectivities and N
and CO working capacities, UiO-66(Zr)-Br appears to have the greatest ability to retain weakly interacting impurities. However, its small pore volume, and hence its lower CO
working capacities, could lead to a shorter overall breakthrough time. UiO-66(Zr), on the other hand, which also exhibits relatively high selectivities, has high CO
working capacities and is expected to display good retention of these strongly interacting impurities. Its lower N

and CO selectivities, however, could lead to a quicker elution of these impurities into the outlet stream. It is difficult to use this information alone to determine which material would be able to selectively adsorb the largest amount of impurities, allow for the longest PSA feed step, and require the lowest amount of purge gas during the regeneration step.

As mentioned earlier, the length of the PSA purge step is limited by the ease of CO

desorption from the bed. Currently, PSA units employ layered beds containing two or more adsorbents. This technique aims to adsorb each impurity within a layer from which it can be readily desorbed. Alumina or silica layers are used to adsorb water vapor, whereas activated carbon is used to target CO

and long hydrocarbons. These strongly adsorbing impurities are thus prevented from reaching the zeolite layer, from which they would be difficult to remove. In the work of Ribeiro et al., a layered bed containing activated carbon and zeolite was modeled as part of an eight-step PSA cycle, and an outlet stream purity of 99.9994% was obtained.
Considering that some MOFs in this study have high heats of adsorption for CO
, particularly UiO-66(Zr)-Br, it is likely that the use of MOFs in layered adsorption beds along with activated carbon would prove to be more efficient than the use of a MOF-only bed.
